title: Reasoning Does Not Necessarily Improve Role-Playing Ability
author: Xiachong Feng (The University of Hong Kong), Longxu Dou (Sea AI Lab), Lingpeng Kong (The University of Hong Kong), ...
relevance_why: The exploration of role-playing abilities in large language models could inform approaches to generative audio and speech tasks that involve character consistency and emotional expression.
background: The study investigates whether advanced reasoning techniques can enhance the role-playing capabilities of large language models in generating character-specific dialogue.
contribution: This paper introduces a comparative evaluation of various role-playing methods across multiple benchmarks, showing that reasoning techniques can degrade performance in role-playing tasks.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods primarily focused on the direct application of reasoning techniques such as Chain-of-Thought (CoT), often leading to performance loss in dialogue generation.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work reveals that using reasoning-optimized models can diminish character fidelity and emotional expression, contrasting with earlier assumptions about the benefits of reasoning.

key_innovation: The research challenges the assumption that reasoning improves role-playing performance, highlighting that complex reasoning can distract from character consistency.
real_world_impact: The findings could influence the development of conversational agents and virtual characters, emphasizing the need for balance between reasoning and character portrayal.
limitations: The study may not cover all possible models and benchmarks, which could affect the generalizability of the conclusions.

new_terms.Chain-of-Thought (CoT): **Chain-of-Thought reasoning** is a method where models articulate their reasoning process in a sequential manner before arriving at a conclusion, often used to improve performance in complex tasks.

open_sourcing: All code has been integrated into OpenCompass, ensuring reproducibility and transparency in experimental procedures.
